title-group.article-title: The journey to autism: Insights from neuroimaging studies of infants and toddlers

author-notes.corresp: Address correspondence and reprint requests to: Jason J. Wolff or Jed T. Elison, University of Minnesota, 250 EdSciB, 56 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55455; jjwolff@umn.edu or jtelison@umn.edu

abstract.p: By definition, autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that emerges during early childhood. It is during this time that infants and toddlers transition from appearing typical across multiple domains to exhibiting the behavioral phenotype of ASD. Neuroimaging studies focused on this period of development have provided crucial knowledge pertaining to this process, including possible mechanisms underlying pathogenesis of the disorder and offering the possibility of prodromal or presymptomatic prediction of risk. In this paper, we review findings from structural and functional brain imaging studies of ASD focused on the first years of life and discuss implications for next steps in research and clinical applications.
